Thanks a lot for the very informative reply!

And I'm very glad to see that there is someone else using heritrix for
linguistic/nlp purposes...

I'm running my second crawl job by following your advice very closely.

> Note that this excludes ".au", which can be problematic if you are
> fetching documents from domains in Australia, since the DNS request
> gets filtered and this is a required prerequisite, so the entire site
> gets filtered.

How comes Australia is filtered out?

> called Vilistextum to extract the text from the HTML in all of the
> extracted files.

Cool! (Also, nice name...)

> This scratches the surface. For the Tagalog and Vietnamese crawls we
> seeded using techniques described in your BootCat papers, and we've
> thought about how to integrate BootCat type processes into Heritrix
> proper, but for now we do it separately using some Java apps 
utilizing
> the Google API and our language identifier technology.

Indeed, right now, I'm seeding my crawls using the top pages found by
Google for English queries made of two randomly combined words from a
random selection of mid-frequency BNC terms.

Once I understand more about Heritrix, I would be happy to help out with
the project of integrating BootCat-like seeding methods into it.

(Right now, I seem to have out of memory problems, having tried a broad 
scope crawl... still a lot to learn! ;-) )

Thanks again!

Regards,

Marco
